poem:
The Mist-Mawg's Morn

'Twas brillig in the fogling morn, 
The vaper-whorls did cloy and cling.
Beware the Mist-Mawg, child forlorn!
Its gwomping jaws and frosty sting!

He took his plowter sword in hand,
And sought the foe through fizzly fenn. 
Slogged squishy swomps of spoggy sand, 
Past toothy trees of boggling fen.

Creeped up in whush, the Mist-Mawg rose!
Its frosking fume encoiled round.
But one, two, three! The plowter goes!
The gwomping gast sprawls on the ground! 

O gloryful day! The Mist-Mawg's slain!
Now dance we jub in safe snug hall!
While fogling sun burns off the bane,
Clear beams its gleam on wuvving all!

So mimsy morn is free at last,
Of vaper-whorls that cloy and cling.
The Mist-Mawg gwomps now in the past,
And all may walk and galth and sing!

poem:
The Pathparoo's Prance

'Twas grissig, on the slithy glade,
The loamling trees a-sway.
A trampled track had waysers made—
A wending wightish way.

Beware the Pathparoo, my son!
The hooves that pound, the mane ahorse!
Trek armored 'gainst the stamping one,
His galumphing, grievous force.

He took his varding blade in hand,
Tracked long the hoof-hewn hash.
Then palsied in the bosky band,
He spied its eyes a-flash!

Clash-slashing through the brush they fought—
Stout sword 'gainst pawing pounds!
The Pathparoo he deftly caught,
And felled in thudding sounds.

"Callooh! Callay!" his cry did ring,
As home his way he wode.
The wending path would no more bring
The hoof-hewn, beaten road.

'Tis grissig, on the slithy glade,
The loamling trees a-sway.
Yet safe the wightish way remade,
The Pathparoo's prance at bay!

And now when brillig comes around,
In conference rooms with glossy sheen,
They reminisce on glories found,
